Insight #3: Tag featured speakers/hosts. 

The most obvious reason this post gained traction? 

I tagged Justin and he quickly commented. 

"Thanks for listening to me ramble on, Geoff. Cheers." 

That opened up the floodgates for his 178k followers to also see the post.

Here are my chicken-scratch notes during the @JustinSaaS webinar. Right after I spent 5 min jotting down a few bullet points, then stepped away for 24 hours. 

I returned, reviewed, and spent 20 min writing them up into a summary. https://t.co/1ws6VIl8pd

📝Insight #2: Practice powerful note-taking

• Take notes by hand. It's more effective for encoding information than on ⌨️ 

• Rewrite notes to consolidate new insights and make connections to prior knowledge. 🧠

• Take a break, then review notes, to process and organize info

✍️ Insight #1: Don't just attend webinars. Write about them. 

People write about favorite books, podcasts, or Twitter threads. 

Why not virtual events? Event recaps are timely, relevant, and offer ICYMI value for people who miss.

I spent 20 minutes writing up notes from the @JustinSaaS #ship30 webinar a few days ago.

24 hours later ----> 20k impressions.

3 tips for conducting your first email interview:
 
1. Write down a few questions you'd like to ask. 

2. People like to be helpful. Flatter their expertise. 

3. Explain why you're interested in this. Personalize and do your homework.

The general practice of posing thoughtful questions will make you a better professional communicator. 

It will help you stay curious, curate new ideas, and grow your network.

Essay #16: How our memory is changing in the age of technology #ship30for30 @dickiebush @Nicolascole77 https://t.co/qyaw55uz4L

Is this an example of the internet making me stupid? 

That's a prevailing fear for people.

In general, people believe the internet’s benefits outweigh the costs. But our top concern is the impact it's having on our brains.

For example, I've forgotten how to calculate percent change, even though I need it a lot for writing. But many yrs ago I found a simple % change calculator online. It's way faster than anything I could ever do manually. https://t.co/mjCSoaP1Dw https://t.co/EMsPftQfqN

Second, the way we forget is changing. 

Our brains are evolved for efficiency. They: 
– look for shortcuts
– make calculated adjustments 
– retrieve information as needed. 

To stay focused on what’s important, our minds forget much more than they remember.

There are at least two ways our memory is changing. 

First, our minds aren't being asked to remember basic stuff anymore, like phone numbers, addresses, or directions. Same for events, appointments, and bdays. 

It's all on our phones, set up w/ notifications and reminders.

Our memory is changing. The internet/tech is definitely to blame. 

But is it making us dumber? 🧵

@TrintHQ is a good paid transcription service that I use a lot.
– It's fast and accurate (~5 min ---> 60min convo) 
– Text from audio content is easily searchable, scannable, and editable. 
– Good for working with teams 
– No free version. $48/mo to start

5. Don't take notes (yet). Read a book chapter, watch a YouTube video, or listen to a podcast. But do it without taking notes. Closeout entirely and then take two minutes to write down EVERYTHING you remember. Open it back up and continue consuming.

4. Mix it up. Even if you don't want to take a break from studying, spend 30 min practicing another skill. Your brain will be sharper when you return. 

Source: Make It Stick: The Science of Successful Learning / @RetrieveLearn https://t.co/WL9m4hx0qH

3. Take breaks. Space out study sessions. It will give your brain more chances to forget info, then remember again. That's a powerful cognitive process. 

Source: Grasp by Sanjay Sarma (via @mssackstein): https://t.co/V2f1XAnsp3

2. Reflect. The small act of pausing to write down your thoughts and questions will help you retain the most important ideas.

How can writers, content creators, journalists – pretty much anyone trying to communicate anything to advance knowledge – change their practices to incorporate "multiple modalities"? Are there visual tools you use that enhance your content? What are they?

What research has shown is that "people learn new material best when they encounter it multiple times and through multiple modalities," as @DerekBruff has written. 

It's not just about semantics and it has implications that reach beyond teaching and learning.

But, fundamentally, the human brain is wired to learn in similar ways. Research has consistently debunked the notion that there are individual learning styles ('I'm a visual learner') 

Yet surveys have shown ~90% of people believe it.

I recently wrote about the pervasive learning style myth.   People do learn differently, process information on different timelines, and have preferred sources for consuming information. We also have different interests and abilities that affect our motivation to learn. https://t.co/hpjTcD7Pnd https://t.co/IrBHeoyZaN
What's your learning style?
